definition: to seek contact with sb for one's own benefit/to suck up to sb
to pull/to play (a bowed instrument)/to drag/to draw/to chat
mountain pass/to close/to shut/to turn off/to concern/to involve
surname Guan
to tie/to fasten/to button up
to connect/to arrest/to worry
to connect/to relate to/to tie up/to bind/to be (literary)
system/department/faculty

sentences.english: Forget rubbing elbows with strangers at networking mixers .
sentences.chinese: 别惦记着和社交网站的陌生人拉关系。

sentences.english: This visit defines the objective and orientation for expanding and deepening China-Latin America ties in the new situation.
sentences.chinese: 为扩大和深化新形势下中拉关系确定了目标和方向。

sentences.english: He said currently bilateral ties have become more mature and enriched.
sentences.chinese: 他说，当前，中拉关系不断走向成熟和充实。

sentences.english: He made contacts with wealthy people in raising money for the project.
sentences.chinese: 为该项工程筹款他与许多有钱人拉关系。

sentences.english: But I would stress, don't "network" compulsively.
sentences.chinese: 不过我想强调，别硬拉关系。

sentences.english: Hu said that China-Latvia relations have made smooth progress since the two countries normalized diplomatic ties.
sentences.chinese: 胡锦涛说，中拉关系正常化以来，两国关系顺利发展。

definition: to try to gain sb's friendship
to worm one's way into being friends with sb (usually derogatory)
see 走門路|走门路[zou3 men2 lu4]
to use social connections/to toady to influential people
to fawn on/to curry favor with/to make up to
to try to form friendly ties with sb for one's own benefit/to suck up to sb
lit. to enter by the back door/fig. to gain influence by pull or unofficial channels/back door or under the counter connections
to seek help from social connections
to smooth whiskers and pat a horse's bottom (idiom); to use flatter to get what one wants/to toady/boot-licking
favoritism shown to sb because of the influence of the person's wife or other female relative/(by extension) favoritism towards relatives, friends or associates
to resort to bragging and flattering
to seek to profit by family ties
to pass a message
to open the back door/fig. under the counter/to do a secret or dishonest deal/to let sth in by the back door
to show deference to sb by obliging them (or by obliging sb associated with them)
to flatter/to fawn on/to butter sb up/toadying/bootlicking
